entries.inflections: (past tense ran /ræn/, past participle run, present participle running)

senses.definition: to move very quickly, by moving your legs more quickly than when you walk

examples.text: I ran down the stairs as fast as I could.
examples.translation: 我尽可能快地跑下楼梯。

examples.text: He was running towards the door.
examples.translation: 他正朝着门口跑去。

examples.text: She turned and ran away.
examples.translation: 她转身跑掉了。

senses.definition: to run in a race

examples.text: I’d never run a marathon before.
examples.translation: 我以前从未参加过马拉松比赛。

examples.text: Murray has said she will consider running in the 3000 metres.
examples.translation: 默里说她将考虑参加3,000米赛跑。

examples.text: The Derby will be run at 3 o'clock.
examples.translation: 德比马赛将于3点钟举行。

senses.definition: to organize or be in charge of an activity, business, organization, or country

examples.text: For a while, she ran a restaurant in Boston.
examples.translation: 有一段时间她在波士顿开餐馆。

examples.text: Many people don’t care who runs the country.
examples.translation: 很多人不在乎由谁统治国家。

examples.text: Courses are currently being run in London and Edinburgh.
examples.translation: 目前伦敦和爱丁堡两地都开设了这些课程。

senses.definition: to do something or go somewhere quickly

examples.text: Run and ask your mother where she’s put the keys.
examples.translation: 快去问你妈﹐她把钥匙放在哪儿了。

examples.text: I need to run to the store for some more milk.
examples.translation: 我得赶快到商店去再买点牛奶。

examples.text: I need to run to the store for some more milk.
examples.translation: 我得赶快到商店去再买点牛奶。

senses.definition: if a bus, train etc service runs, it takes people from one place to another at fixed times

examples.text: The buses don’t run on Sundays.
examples.translation: 公共汽车星期天停驶。

examples.text: The number 61 bus runs to the city centre.
examples.translation: 61路公共汽车开往市中心。

examples.text: They’re running special trains to and from the exhibition.
examples.translation: 他们有往返展览会的专线列车。

senses.definition: if a computer program runs, it operates

examples.text: The software will run on any PC.
examples.translation: 这个软件可在任何一台个人电脑上运行。

examples.text: The RS8 system runs both Unix and MPX-32.
examples.translation: RS8系统既可运行Unix﹐也可运行MPX-32。

examples.text: The software will run on any PC.
examples.translation: 这个软件可在任何一台个人电脑上运行。

senses.definition: if a machine or engine runs, it operates

examples.text: She got out of the car and left the engine running.
examples.translation: 她下了车﹐让引擎开着。

examples.text: Most cars run on unleaded fuel.
examples.translation: 大多数汽车使用无铅汽油。

examples.text: It runs off batteries.
examples.translation: 它装电池使用。

senses.definition: if a tape is running, it is recording

examples.text: She didn’t realize the tape was running as she spoke.
examples.translation: 她没有意识到她说话的时候﹐磁带正在录音。

examples.text: Run the tape back to the beginning.
examples.translation: 把磁带倒到开头。

senses.definition: to print something in a newspaper or magazine, or broadcast something on television

examples.text: The company is running a series of advertisements in national newspapers.
examples.translation: 公司正在全国性报纸上刊登一系列广告。

examples.text: A local TV station ran her story.
examples.translation: 一家地方电视台报道了她的事迹。

examples.text: The series ran for 20 episodes and was extremely popular.
examples.translation: 这个系列片播了20集﹐极受欢迎。

senses.definition: to move too fast or in an uncontrolled way

examples.text: Her car ran off the road and into a tree.
examples.translation: 她的汽车冲出路面﹐撞到一棵树上。

examples.text: The truck ran out of control and hit a house.
examples.translation: 卡车失控﹐撞上了一栋房子。

phrasal_verbs.definition: to meet someone or find something by chance
phrasal_verbs.definition_cn: 与…不期而遇﹐偶然碰见﹔偶然发现

examples.text: I ran across him at a conference in Milan.
examples.translation: 我在米兰的一次大会上碰到过他。

examples.text: I ran across some old love letters while I was clearing out a cupboard.
examples.translation: 我在清理柜子时找到一些旧情书。

examples.text: He ran after her, calling her name.
examples.translation: 他叫着她的名字在后面追她。

phrasal_verbs.definition: used to tell a child to leave, or to tell someone that you must leave
phrasal_verbs.definition_cn: 走开〔用于命令小孩〕﹔离开〔用于告诉别人你得走了〕

examples.text: Run along now! I’ve got work to finish.
examples.translation: 赶紧走开！我有工作要完成。

examples.text: Oh, it’s late. I’d better be running along.
examples.translation: 噢﹐时候不早了﹐我得走了。

phrasal_verbs.definition: to run in an area while you are playing

examples.text: The children were running around in the garden.
examples.translation: 孩子们在花园里跑来跑去。

phrasal_verbs.definition: to do a lot of things for someone else as though you were their servant

examples.text: I’ve spent all day running around after the kids.
examples.translation: 我整天都在侍候孩子们。

phrasal_verbs.definition: to spend a lot of time with someone, especially someone that other people disapprove of

examples.text: He started running around with a gang of teenagers.
examples.translation: 他开始和一帮小混混厮混。

phrasal_verbs.definition: to leave a place, especially secretly, in order to escape from someone or something

examples.text: Toby ran away from home at the age of 14.
examples.translation: 托比14岁时离家出走。

examples.text: Toby ran away from home at the age of 14.
examples.translation: 托比14岁时离家出走。

phrasal_verbs.definition: to secretly go away with someone in order to marry them or live with them – usually used to show disapproval

examples.text: His wife has run away with another man.
examples.translation: 他的妻子跟别的男人走了。

phrasal_verbs.definition: to tell someone something so that they can give you their opinion
phrasal_verbs.definition_cn: 〔为征询意见〕把〔某事〕告诉〔某人〕

examples.text: Let me run some figures by you.
examples.translation: 我给你说几个数据吧。

examples.text: I just wanted to run it past you and see what you thought.
examples.translation: 我只是想说给你听听﹐看看你有什么想法。

phrasal_verbs.definition: to drive into a person or animal and kill or injure them

examples.text: Their daughter was run down by a car.
examples.translation: 他们的女儿被车撞了。

simple_forms.person: I, you, he, she, it, we, they
I, you, he, she, it, we, they
I, you, he, she, it, we, they
I, you, he, she, it, we, they

continuous_forms.person: I, you, he, she, it, we, they
I, you, he, she, it, we, they
I, you, he, she, it, we, they

entries.definition: to move very quickly, by moving your legs more quickly than when you walk跑
examples: My five-year-old son runs everywhere.我五岁大的儿子到处跑。
I go running twice a week.我一星期跑步两次。

entries.definition: to run quite slowly for exercise over a long distance慢跑
examples: A few people were jogging in the park.一些人在公园里慢跑。

entries.definition: to run somewhere as quickly as you can, especially because you have to do something urgently飞奔
examples: He dashed across the road to the police station.他飞快地穿过马路奔向警察局。
We raced to the bus stop and got there just in time.我们奔到公共汽车站﹐刚好赶上。

entries.definition: to run as fast as you can for a short distance〔短距离〕冲刺
examples: I saw the runners sprinting past.我看到选手们冲了过去。
He sprinted up the stairs.他飞奔上楼。

entries.definition: to run very quickly and without really looking where you are going, because you are in a hurry狂奔
examples: He tore down the street and around the corner.他在街上飞奔﹐然后转过街角。

entries.definition: to run quickly and with a lot of energy, so that you might knock down anyone or anything that gets in your way猛冲
examples: They all charged out of the school gates at 4 o'clock.一到4点﹐他们全都冲出校门。
Dennis charged through the door into my office.

entries.definition: to start running away very quickly, especially to escape or because you are afraid逃跑
examples: The men took to their heels as soon as they saw the police.那些男子一看到警察就逃。

entries.definition: to run away very quickly, in order to escape from someone or something
examples: I legged it before the cops came.

entries.definition: to run easily with long steps – used especially about tall people with long legs
examples: John loped across the street to meet me.

entries.definition: to run fairly slowly, taking short steps – used especially about horses and dogs〔尤指马和狗〕小跑
examples: A little dog was trotting behind her.一只小狗跟在她身后跑。

senses.definition: a period of time spent running, or a distance that you run

examples.text: a five-mile run
examples.translation: 五英里跑

examples.text: She usually goes for a run before breakfast.
examples.translation: 她通常在早餐前去跑步。

examples.text: He was still following me, and in a panic I broke into a run.
examples.translation: 他仍然在尾随我﹐我吓得跑了起来。

senses.definition: later in the future, not immediately

examples.text: Moving to Spain will be better for you in the long run.
examples.translation: 从长远来看﹐搬到西班牙对你更合适。

senses.definition: in the near future

examples.text: Sufficient supply, in the short run, will be a problem.
examples.translation: 短期内能否有充足供应将会是个问题。

senses.definition: the usual type of something
senses.definition_cn: 一般/正常/普遍类型的某事物

examples.text: The place was very different from the normal run of street cafes.

senses.definition: a series of successes or failures
senses.definition_cn: 一连串﹐一系列〔成功或失败〕

examples.text: an unbeaten run of 19 games
examples.translation: 连续19场不败

examples.text: Losing my job was the start of a run of bad luck that year.
examples.translation: 失业是我那年一连串霉运的开始。

examples.text: His extraordinary run of successes has been stopped.
examples.translation: 他那种无往不利的成功势头已经结束。

senses.definition: an amount of a product produced at one time

examples.text: a limited run of 200 copies
examples.translation: 200册的限量

senses.definition: to be trying to escape or hide, especially from the police
senses.definition_cn: 在逃跑﹐在躲藏〔尤指为逃避警察〕

examples.text: wanted criminals on the run from police
examples.translation: 逃避警方追捕的通缉犯

examples.text: Typical of stress is this feeling of being continuously on the run.
examples.translation: 这种一直奔波不停的感觉就是压力的典型表现。

examples.text: wanted criminals on the run from police
examples.translation: 逃避警方追捕的通缉犯

senses.definition: to do something while you are on your way somewhere or doing something else
senses.definition_cn: 在赶路[做其他事]的时候做某事

examples.text: I always seem to eat on the run these days.
examples.translation: 这些天我好像总是边赶路边吃饭。

senses.definition: to suddenly start running, in order to escape
if you have the run of a place, you are allowed to go anywhere and do anything in it

examples.text: We had the run of the house for the afternoon.
examples.translation: 下午我们可以在房子里自由活动。

extra_examples.text: a 5-mile run
After his run, he took a long shower.
Both resorts offer beginner to expert runs.
Camilli scored 936 runs in 12 major-league seasons.
Dunaway is starring in a six-week run of "Master Class" in Los Angeles.
Long distance runners follow a different training programme from other athletes.

examples: You'll have to run or you'll miss the bus.
He kept on running until he was out in the open country.
A dog ran straight out in front of my car.

entries.definition: to run very quickly for a short distance, especially because you have to do something urgently
examples: Gillian saw two men dash past, but they didn't notice her.
I eventually found the place, and dashed up the stairs.
We only have a few moments, because Heidi's got to dash off soon.

entries.definition: to start running quickly towards a place or thing to try to reach it or escape something
examples: It was raining, and we made a run for the car.
When the lecture was finally ovr, the students made a break for the exit.
As soon as the guard turns around, we'll make a run for it.

entries.definition: to run as fast as you can, usually over a short distance
examples: Margaret sprinted down the street, almost collapsing when she reached us.
The bus driver must have seen me sprinting for the bus, but he drove off.

entries.definition: to run fairly slowly, taking short steps
examples: She trotted softly through the passageway to the gate.
I looked up, and saw a dog trotting along the sidewalk toward me.
Dorothy arrived, with a little dog trotting along behind her.

entries.definition: to run very quickly and without really looking where you are going, because you are in a hurry狂奔
examples: Bobby tore past, shouting something about being late for work.
A masked man came tearing out of the bank and jumped into a waiting car.
Mary tore off downstairs, determined to see the visitors for herself.

entries.definition: to run quickly and with a lot of energy, especially when you are going to attack someone or something
examples: The doors flew open, and Pascoe charged across the foyer, scattering people in all directions.
Riot police with batons charged at soccer fans twice during last night's international with Spain.
Don't charge off, I want a word with you.

entries.definition: to suddenly start running, especially after you have been walking
examples: Suddenly two of the prisoners broke into a run, heading as fast as they could for the fence.
He walked swiftly, resisting the urge to break into a run.

entries.definition: to move quickly forward with long high jumps
examples: A big black Alsatian dog came bounding up to her.
There was a shout, and suddenly Adrian bounded into the room.

entries.definition: to run in a race or for exercise
examples: I think I'll probably run for about 40 minutes, then come back for a shower.
She runs a couple of miles twice a week.
I ran four miles Saturday, and I can tell you I was exhausted after it.
